title: 109_s1006
content: The Act "State Criminal Alien Assistance Program II" provides financial assistance to States and local governments for costs incurred in processing illegal immigrants through their law enforcement and criminal justice systems, including reimbursement for indirect costs related to the incarceration of illegal aliens. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to include reimbursement for costs incurred by States and local governments for imprisoning illegal aliens convicted of felonies, as well as indirect costs related to their imprisonment. The definition of indirect costs includes expenses for court proceedings, attorneys, and detention of illegal aliens. The Immigration Reform and Control Act of 1986 is amended to include reimbursement for costs incurred by States and local governments for imprisoning illegal aliens convicted of felonies, as well as indirect costs related to their imprisonment, such as indigent defense, prosecution, autopsies, and translation services. $500,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2009 for this purpose. The Attorney General will allocate funds based on the percentage of undocumented aliens. The Attorney General will allocate $333,000,000 to States and local governments based on the percentage of undocumented aliens in each State compared to the total number nationwide. The Attorney General will allocate $167,000,000 to the 6 States with the highest number of undocumented alien apprehensions, in addition to amounts allocated based on the percentage of undocumented aliens in each State compared to the total nationwide. The allocation of funds to States with high undocumented alien apprehensions is based on the total amount available and the percentage of apprehensions in each State compared to the national total. Data is obtained from the Department of Homeland Security for the highest apprehension rates in the preceding fiscal year.
